I‚Äôm usually the type of guy who stays in the shadows and never posts anything online, but this time I simply can‚Äôt move on without rating this game.

Back in 2013, when I saw the massive hype surrounding The Last of Us, I was frustrated that I didn‚Äôt own a PS3. I ended up spoiling a lot of the experience for myself by watching playthroughs and let‚Äôs plays. As a PC-only gamer, I always dreamed of a proper PC port.

Years passed, and when I heard that The Last of Us was finally coming to PC, I genuinely wondered if it would still be worth playing, considering how much I already knew about the story. Now, even if I‚Äôm more than a decade late to the party, I can finally answer that question.

And oh my god, YES ! It was absolutely worth it.

Experiencing the game firsthand completely blew me away. Even though I already knew most major story beats, I was still captivated from start to finish. It ended up becoming my favorite game of all time.

The Last of Us is a mature, emotionally rich narrative with exceptional pacing. Every piece of dialogue lands exactly as it should, some lines hit so hard you feel them in your spine. The writing is elevated even further by Gustavo Santaolalla‚Äôs beautiful, haunting soundtrack, which perfectly reinforces the game‚Äôs emotional moments.

The visuals are stunning as well. The overgrown, post-apocalyptic world nature reclaiming collapsed cities creates an atmosphere that is both eerie and breathtaking. It‚Äôs one of the most immersive worlds I‚Äôve ever stepped into.

Gameplay-wise, the main combat loop is incredibly satisfying. Whether you approach encounters aggressively or with full stealth, the game supports both playstyles with a strong variety of weapons and tools.

I played The Last of Us in both English and French, and the voice acting was exceptional in both versions. The performances truly carry the emotional weight of the story.

As for optimization : yes, the game had a rough launch on PC, but as of now it runs smoothly. I personally experienced zero bugs, zero frame drops nothing that took away from the experience.

I enjoyed every single second of this game, and I can easily see myself replaying it in the future. When the final scene ended and the credits rolled, it hit me so hard that I just sat there for a moment, speechless.

The Last of Us Part I has over the years and through many updates, become a much easier and smoother experience on pc. If you've heard of the series and want to play through a pretty good narrative about a father and daughter odyssey through a post-apocalyptic world infested by a mycelium zombie virus with all the moral dilemmas that can generate then you're set. The problem i have with the game is down to gameplay, stealth and combat can feel incredibly shallow at times with uncommon exceptions. As a narratively focused game, it's a fun experience but outside of that it struggles to find an appeal for another playthrough. Keep that in mind if you're looking for value.

While certain enemies do shake up the formula, most of the time what you'll be doing in stealth from hour 1 will be the same by the end. The action gameplay is very by the numbers and isn't very innovating either, while the limited ammo nature feels tense at times.. it's not really enough to shake things up. It's very railroaded on both of those fronts. It does feel like the game does try to make an attempt to add some depth but it's just not enough to keep the fun going by the end. TLOU:P1 ultimately feels like it really spins it's wheels by the end on the gameplay end, the narrative really is the thing that keeps you going.

Do i think TLOU is a good game on the gameplay standpoint? Yeah i think it's a pretty solid experience but i don't think it's the rave hit game that everyone thinks it is, it clearly has weakness in it's gameplay. It feels trapped between three worlds, the action, the survival horror aspects of the game and the stealth and they don't particularly mesh that well at least in age. Other games have managed a better synergy, Alan Wake 2 as an example marries the pump shotgun action with that desperation of scrounging for ammo much better and functions better as a horror game than TLOU. And as a stealth game, it just is too shallow. Throw distraction, pick off enemy. Throw another. Pick off enemy. 

The Narrative is good, it's maybe a little bit of a slow burn for the first 6 hours with the intro being the exception but it gives you a good glimpse into how dire the world is and the personalities of it's main characters. I had zero complaints with how the art is handled in this game, it's fantastic. It perfectly marries post-modern american architecture with the post-apocalyptic aesthetic. Nature taking back an increasingly distant past of what was modern civilization and you see a lot of that. It's very melancholic. I won't spoil the characters, the story or anything because it really is that special sauce that makes the game standout. I will however quickly interject that the TV Show really develops it a lot more and is generally a higher quality of story but in terms of immersion factor the game is solid.

The remaster itself is probably the best experience you're going to get out of the game, certain quality of life features and more fun nic-naks do add onto the base experience if you've ever played the original PS3 version. If it's worth ¬£50? That's a lot more debatable. I think maybe at half price at around ¬£25, it's a no brainer price. You'll enjoy your time but ¬£50 is a tall order for what is essentially a 10-14 hour game. It's on your own definition and you'll have to decide the tiebreaker here. Ultimately you'll likely have a good time with this one.

I waited to play The Last of Us Part I for quite a while. One of the reasons was because how broken this port was on launch. I did encounter a few freezes here and there and on one occasion my entire pc had to be rebooted. I was able to stay at a pretty consistent 60 fps following a reddit optimazation guide.

The game has really gorgeous visuals. Cutscenes are really high quality with character models of Ellie and Joel so detailed to the point where they look really lifelike. Combat is simple, yet effective. The guns feel good to use but, I wish the shotgun was stronger. The game has really good PS5 DualSense controller implementation which makes everything really immersive. I played on a custom difficulty with everything set to Survivor except from loot which I set to Hard. I don't love stealth and I had heard that with how scarce loot becomes on Survivor or above you are really incentivized to use stealth. If enemies are going to be more accurate, spot you quicker and more aggressive I want loot to deal with the situation without being forced to stealth. I got killed quite a few times, especially early on because of being reckless but, overall the Survivor difficulty felt pretty fair and not having listen mode made the game a lot more tense. I played at a slow pace, especially inbetween enemy encounters so I could loot as much as possible. I'd say the pacing of the game is pretty much perfect, there are enough interesting gameplay setpieces to keep you engaged. The weakest part of the game by far are the puzzles. There are like 3 different kinds of puzzles: Push a floating board made of wood to assist Ellie across water, Push a dumpster or similar objects to a ledge so you can jump it or find a ladder. The story is and how characters are written are the best part of the game, and several moments had me emotional even though I had watched someone play the game before and watched the show. It is definitely an experience that will stick with me for a while.

Finally got round to playing 'one of the best games of all time', 10 years after release and having already watched the TV show that followed, I feel like I've somehow had the rug pulled out under my feet. While I can't honestly say that any part of the game is plainly bad, it's obvious that a massive internet hive-mind frenzy is responsible for the surge of awards, acclaim, and outright hysteria that follows the series to this day.

It has to be admitted that the remaster's graphics are incredible, although turning them up to their true maximums will tax the vast majority of PC's. Sadly despite this, the developers fall into the same trap as so many other groups, where a truly fantastic level of graphic fidelity ends up utterly ruined by constantly covering everything in fog, dust, smog, mist, blinding rain, or if those aren't good enough, just outright darkness to the point where everything is just shadows on shadows. The sections where actual light is allowed to get through do look excellent though, and are spaced throughout the game.

Sound design overall can only really be described as 'good'. All generally well crafted, but nothing particularly stands out as amazing, and music is sparse but well placed.

This is where the praise ends however. Gameplay overall is painfully linear, and even allowing for the fact it's technically 10 years old, it's just dull. There is literally nothing in here that hasn't been done before, and better, elsewhere. A particular annoyance was just how gamified the resources and ammo systems were, in an attempt to enforce an atmosphere of constantly scrabbling for kit and scavenging. By the end of the game Joel is carrying 3 different hand guns, a sawn-off shotty, a full size shotgun, a hunting rifle, a full size bow, an assault rifle, and a literal flamethrower (as well as 9 different grenades), but at no point can you ever carry more than around 30 or so bullets for any of them.

Silent melee kills on dangerous enemies have to be done with crafted shivs which break upon use, and the same shivs are also used to unlock optional loot doors, while the parts to make them can't always be easily found; creating a choice between silent combat and getting more loot. Joel's been living as a smuggler in an apocalypse for years without ever finding a fixed blade knife? You can carry around up to 3 pre-made large health kits, but the small chocolate bars and snacks found lying around can only be eaten on the spot (because they're just a replacement for what would have been a glowing +5 health icon 10 years before). Of course you can't put those in your backpack, that's where you keep your 9 guns.

For a game that loves to bash you over the head with the idea of using stealth combat where necessary, the actual stealth mechanics sure are basic. The earlier complaint about how everything is dark means the game has to literally pop up a UI note to advise that you can leave your flashlight on when dealing with zombies, because it won't attract them (convenient). Enemies that are described as 'flanking' are really just pathfinding to your exact spot but being forced to detour to the side; if you sit and watch them they will always end up right next to you, even if they have ranged weapons that would let them sit back. Fire literal hand cannons within 20 feet of someone but move 10 feet to the side and you've 'vanished', so off they search again.

And then finally, the plot. The most lauded story-based game in what must be nearly 20 years. The plot and storyline must be great, surely? Well, it's functional, and that's about it. Having seen so many franchises where public opinion is that 'the book/game was better than the TV show', here I have to say it feels reversed. The TV show took the bones of a plotline from this game, and made an actual story and characters out of it; the game is just a series of scenarios that Joel slowly grinds through, killing everything as he goes. There are no choices, this is a set-story and you aren't deviating an inch, if you spend too long hanging around an area a big hint will pop up for you to let you know which way to go. I particularly enjoyed the constant running joke of Joel finding and keeping various maps for each area, as though you actually need to navigate.

The characterisation of both Joel and Ellie seems almost deliberately vague, they're both intended as Mary-Sues, and I suspect this is why the show had so many negative responses, because any actor that's not 'you' as Joel, and your own real or imaginary child as Ellie is never going to live up. Joel could be literally any masculine-coded American middle-aged male you care to think of. His backstory is that he used to have a daughter. His personality traits are that he used to have a daughter, and he shoots things. No friends, no beliefs, no known affiliations (alright, one brother, estranged) or life motivations. Even with his 'partner' Tess it's not clear if he even has any attachment to her at all beyond her usefulness as a smuggling accomplice.

Ellie is arguably even worse, despite the fact that the entire game is about her. She essentially pops fully formed into the world at 14 years old, you are given literally no backstory about her whatsoever until the very end of the game via a couple of diary entries, and 3 sentences of dialogue. Her personality is to be unnaturally pleasant and cheerful even for a regular 14 year old girl, let alone one constantly travelling and being attacked by zombies and bandits in an apocalyptic nightmare. She will occasionally raise her voice slightly and curse in the sort of genteel manner that might offend a priest, just to remind you she is in fact supposed to be a teenage girl going through a severe PTSD-inducing traumatic life; but only briefly before returning to her usual state of socially pleasant optimism. Both characters show no signs of change or growth until key plot moments where they are required to, whereupon they suddenly change their minds. Joel in particular spends the entire first half of the game trying to palm Ellie off until the precise moment he's able to; whereupon he immediately becomes a surrogate father and doggedly refuses to let her out of his sight. Ellie chafes at the idea of anyone telling her what to do, or treating her like the child she actually is, but accepts her being smuggled to the Fireflies and out of the safety of the QZ without so much as a murmur, if not actively assisting this despite how much danger it puts her in.

The plot itself is as basic as can be, leveraging the background of the scenario (zombies, yo) as justification for a lack of any explanatory detail whatsoever. FEDRA is bad, they have no interest in a cure,  would kill Ellie on sight, and only care about maintaining dictatorial control. You know this because you are told so by a Firefly (rebel group working against FEDRA). No further arguments, no other evidence or justification, you never even speak to a FEDRA aligned character who has a name to present an opposing opinion. Joel as the PC is initially motivated only by money / supplies, and takes the job of smuggling Ellie without even knowing why she is important; he could quite literally be trafficking a 14 year old sex slave and doesn't question it. Yet contrarily, he also appears to be the only person who has any issue with killing Ellie in the final act. It's just accepted that although a few people wring their hands for a while, ultimately the entire Firefly group goes along with murdering a child, to the point that almost the entire Firefly population dies at Joel's hands trying to stop him.

Overall, I wonder if I'd been able to play this when it first came out, I may have felt less critical to it, but without nostalgia goggles on, this feels like a case of Playstation fans experiencing heavy buyers remorse and tribal bias, resulting in an internet group-think that decided a 7/10 game is somehow an 11/10,

Finally got round to playing 'one of the best games of all time', 10 years after release and having already watched the TV show that followed, I feel like I've somehow had the rug pulled out under my feet. While I can't honestly say that any part of the game is plainly bad, it's obvious that a massive internet hive-mind frenzy is responsible for the surge of awards, acclaim, and outright hysteria that follows the series to this day.

It has to be admitted that the remaster's graphics are incredible, although turning them up to their true maximums will tax the vast majority of PC's. Sadly despite this, the developers fall into the same trap as so many other groups, where a truly fantastic level of graphic fidelity ends up utterly ruined by constantly covering everything in fog, dust, smog, mist, blinding rain, or if those aren't good enough, just outright darkness to the point where everything is just shadows on shadows. The sections where actual light is allowed to get through do look excellent though, and are spaced throughout the game.

Sound design overall can only really be described as 'good'. All generally well crafted, but nothing particularly stands out as amazing, and music is sparse but well placed.

This is where the praise ends however. Gameplay overall is painfully linear, and even allowing for the fact it's technically 10 years old, it's just dull. There is literally nothing in here that hasn't been done before, and better, elsewhere. A particular annoyance was just how gamified the resources and ammo systems were, in an attempt to enforce an atmosphere of constantly scrabbling for kit and scavenging. By the end of the game Joel is carrying 3 different hand guns, a sawn-off shotty, a full size shotgun, a hunting rifle, a full size bow, an assault rifle, and a literal flamethrower (as well as 9 different grenades), but at no point can you ever carry more than around 30 or so bullets for any of them.

Silent melee kills on dangerous enemies have to be done with crafted shivs which break upon use, and the same shivs are also used to unlock optional loot doors, while the parts to make them can't always be easily found; creating a choice between silent combat and getting more loot. Joel's been living as a smuggler in an apocalypse for years without ever finding a fixed blade knife? You can carry around up to 3 pre-made large health kits, but the small chocolate bars and snacks found lying around can only be eaten on the spot (because they're just a replacement for what would have been a glowing +5 health icon 10 years before). Of course you can't put those in your backpack, that's where you keep your 9 guns.

For a game that loves to bash you over the head with the idea of using stealth combat where necessary, the actual stealth mechanics sure are basic. The earlier complaint about how everything is dark means the game has to literally pop up a UI note to advise that you can leave your flashlight on when dealing with zombies, because it won't attract them (convenient). Enemies that are described as 'flanking' are really just pathfinding to your exact spot but being forced to detour to the side; if you sit and watch them they will always end up right next to you, even if they have ranged weapons that would let them sit back. Fire literal hand cannons within 20 feet of someone but move 10 feet to the side and you've 'vanished', so off they search again.

And then finally, the plot. The most lauded story-based game in what must be nearly 20 years. The plot and storyline must be great, surely? Well, it's functional, and that's about it. Having seen so many franchises where public opinion is that 'the book/game was better than the TV show', here I have to say it feels reversed. The TV show took the bones of a plotline from this game, and made an actual story and characters out of it; the game is just a series of scenarios that Joel slowly grinds through, killing everything as he goes. There are no choices, this is a set-story and you aren't deviating an inch, if you spend too long hanging around an area a big hint will pop up for you to let you know which way to go. I particularly enjoyed the constant running joke of Joel finding and keeping various maps for each area, as though you actually need to navigate.

The characterisation of both Joel and Ellie seems almost deliberately vague, they're both intended as Mary-Sues, and I suspect this is why the show had so many negative responses, because any actor that's not 'you' as Joel, and your own real or imaginary child as Ellie is never going to live up. Joel could be literally any masculine-coded American middle-aged male you care to think of. His backstory is that he used to have a daughter. His personality traits are that he used to have a daughter, and he shoots things. No friends, no beliefs, no known affiliations (alright, one brother, estranged) or life motivations. Even with his 'partner' Tess it's not clear if he even has any attachment to her at all beyond her usefulness as a smuggling accomplice.

Ellie is arguably even worse, despite the fact that the entire game is about her. She essentially pops fully formed into the world at 14 years old, you are given literally no backstory about her whatsoever until the very end of the game via a couple of diary entries, and 3 sentences of dialogue. Her personality is to be unnaturally pleasant and cheerful even for a regular 14 year old girl, let alone one constantly travelling and being attacked by zombies and bandits in an apocalyptic nightmare. She will occasionally raise her voice slightly and curse in the sort of genteel manner that might offend a priest, just to remind you she is in fact supposed to be a teenage girl going through a severe PTSD-inducing traumatic life; but only briefly before returning to her usual state of socially pleasant optimism. Both characters show no signs of change or growth until key plot moments where they are required to, whereupon they suddenly change their minds. Joel in particular spends the entire first half of the game trying to palm Ellie off until the precise moment he's able to; whereupon he immediately becomes a surrogate father and doggedly refuses to let her out of his sight. Ellie chafes at the idea of anyone telling her what to do, or treating her like the child she actually is, but accepts her being smuggled to the Fireflies and out of the safety of the QZ without so much as a murmur, if not actively assisting this despite how much danger it puts her in.

The plot itself is as basic as can be, leveraging the background of the scenario (zombies, yo) as justification for a lack of any explanatory detail whatsoever. FEDRA is bad, they have no interest in a cure,  would kill Ellie on sight, and only care about maintaining dictatorial control. You know this because you are told so by a Firefly (rebel group working against FEDRA). No further arguments, no other evidence or justification, you never even speak to a FEDRA aligned character who has a name to present an opposing opinion. Joel as the PC is initially motivated only by money / supplies, and takes the job of smuggling Ellie without even knowing why she is important; he could quite literally be trafficking a 14 year old sex slave and doesn't question it. Yet contrarily, he also appears to be the only person who has any issue with killing Ellie in the final act. It's just accepted that although a few people wring their hands for a while, ultimately the entire Firefly group goes along with murdering a child, to the point that almost the entire Firefly population dies at Joel's hands trying to stop him.

Overall, I wonder if I'd been able to play this when it first came out, I may have felt less critical to it, but without nostalgia goggles on, this feels like a case of Playstation fans experiencing heavy buyers remorse and tribal bias, resulting in an internet group-think that decided a 7/10 game is somehow an 11/10,
